Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Integrative Approach to Predicting Amphibian Chytridiomycosis in Space and Time
Award.AbstractNarration:
The seasonal cycles exhibited by many infectious diseases are a reminder of the effects of climate on host-pathogen interactions, yet the mechanisms that link environmental variation to epidemiological patterns are often poorly understood. A clearer understanding of the relationship between climate and host-pathogen interactions is needed to predict and mitigate the risks that infectious diseases pose to humans and wildlife. The amphibian chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) causes the disease chytridiomycosis, which has been linked to declines and extinctions of frogs worldwide and appears to be an important contributor to the ongoing amphibian extinction crisis. This project will contribute to our understanding of the epidemiology of this host-pathogen interaction by clarifying the behavioral and immunological mechanisms by which climatic variation shapes the risk of chytridiomycosis in amphibians. The project team will integrate research and education through the development of middle school, high school and university level curricula. Using the amphibian chytridiomycosis system as a model, they will develop learning modules centered on teaching how changes in climate, via their effects on physiology, can impact ecological processes.

The project team will quantify the relationship between climate, host behavior and Bd susceptibility and use it to (1) make spatiotemporal predictions of disease risk and (2) teach K-12 and university students about the potential impacts of climate change on ecosystems. The research component of this project will assess (I) the effect of temperature on pathogenicity and immune defense, and (II) the effectiveness of a behavioral fever response in combating Bd infection using lab exposure experiments under a variety of thermal conditions. Concurrently, host body temperatures and available microclimates will be measured in the field to determine (III) how the opportunity for thermally-mediated host defense varies in space and time. Ultimately, the findings of objectives I - III will be used to develop biophysical models (IV) to predict where and when amphibians will be unable avoid or combat Bd, leaving them susceptible to mortality and declines. The education component of this project will use findings and techniques from the research to develop, employ, and evaluate new curricula for teaching the impacts of climate change on ecological processes. At the core of these curricula will be experiential learning and a "citizen science" approach, facilitating feedback from K-12 and university classrooms to the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fungal pathogens are increasingly recognized as drivers of wildlife declines and extinctions. The major research goal of this project was to improve our understanding of the epidemiology of one such threat by clarifying the behavioral and immunological mechanisms by which climatic variation shapes the risk of chytridiomycosis in amphibians. Using the amphibian-Bd system as an example, our work aimed to demonstrate how the integration of lab, field and modeling approaches can provide important insights into mechanisms linking environmental variation to the potential impact of emerging infectious diseases.

The major education goal of this project was to develop and disseminate climate change curriculum for middle school classrooms that fills a need for teachers and students and also generates data that fed back into our research.

Three PhD students, five undergraduate REU students and four RET teachers were trained in biology research in association with this project.  The majority of these participants contributed to authorship on publications and/or gave presentations at professional meetings helping to disseminate the results of the research and education efforts.

We used experiments to quantify the effect of temperature on the interaction with Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), the pathogen that causes chytridiomycosis, in the Northern cricket frog, Acris crepitans. We found that host survival and disease variables decreased with increasing temperature. This work was published in the journal Ecohealth in 2017. We collaborated with several other labs to study the occurrence of behavioral fever, and potentially important behavioral defense against Bd, in a range of amphibian species. We did not find strong evidence for behavioral fever. Instead, individual thermal preferences seem to be important in determining the course and outcome of an infection with Bd. These results were published in the journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B in 2018. We conducted a multi-year field study including populations that spanned the extant range of Acris creptans to learn about the role of climate in disease dynamics. We found strong relationships between temperature and Bd prevalence and infection intensity and weaker but significant relationships with precipitation. These results, along with results from a lab study where frogs were exposed to Bd under daily fluctuating temperatures that mimicked seasonal extremes for the species, were published in Ecosphere in 2019. We also ran experiments to understand how temperature impacts host defenses against Bd, including

antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) and beneficial bacteria in the skin microbiome. We found that frogs renew their stores of AMPs more slowly and are more susceptible to mortality whenexposed to Bd at low temperatures. Beneficial bacteria were also more effective against Bd at low temperatures. These results were published in Frontiers in Micriobiology in 2018 and the Journal of Experimental Biology in 2019, respectively. Finally, we integrated all the aforementioned research results into a biophysical model study how a frog’s susceptibility to infection and mortality due to chytridiomycosis over its extant range and across seasons. The modeling approach and predictions were published in Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution in 2020.

For our education objective, we developed a curriculum module called Ectotherm ER, geared toward middle school and/or early high school science classrooms, that engages students in collecting data to understand the impacts of climate and climate change on ectothermic animals and how that impact may translate to disease (and other conservation) risk. The curriculum was published in the National Science Teachers Association's journal Science Scope (it's journal geared toward middle school science teachers) in 2021. The curriculum is also now part of the required science curriculum in Pittsburgh Public Schools and several other school districts.
